question: If index fossil species existed only for a short time, what is true about them today?

content.source_1: Index fossils are fossils of species that were widespread but geologically short‑lived; their narrow stratigraphic ranges make them especially useful for dating rock layers.
content.source_2: When a species’ fossils occur only within a bounded interval of older strata and never in younger rocks, paleontologists infer that the species went extinct after that interval.
content.source_3: Classic index fossils include trilobites (Paleozoic) and ammonites (Mesozoic); both groups are entirely extinct.
content.source_4: The coccolithophore Emiliania huxleyi is a living species whose first appearance in the fossil record is about 0.29 million years ago; its coccoliths are used biostratigraphically to identify late Pleistocene–Holocene marine sediments.
content.source_5: In Quaternary biostratigraphy, first appearances of still‑living microfossil species (e.g., certain planktonic foraminifera and diatoms) are routinely used as index or zonal markers to date very young sediments.
content.source_6: The “Lazarus taxon” phenomenon (e.g., the modern coelacanth) shows that a lineage can disappear from the fossil record for long intervals and later be found alive, cautioning that not all fossil taxa are necessarily extinct.
